parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Replacing or repairing damaged anti-predator nets is an action that can reduce predation by marine mammals at aquaculture systems.
[Statement 2]: One study found that replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
[Statement 3]: Acoustic devices can be used at aquaculture systems.
[Statement 4]: Four of six studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
[Statement 5]: Some studies found that acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
[Statement 6]: Two studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce harbour seal predation.
[Statement 7]: Two studies found that acoustic devices did not affect common bottlenose dolphin behavior around fin-fish farms.
[Statement 8]: Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems has been attempted.
[Statement 9]: Studies found that more than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned.
[Statement 10]: Modifying anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems is a potential action to reduce predation.
[Statement 11]: Minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems is a potential action to reduce predation.
[Statement 12]: Introducing regulations to prevent the use of harmful deterrents is a potential action to reduce predation.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of modifying anti-predator nets, minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems, or introducing regulations to prevent the use of harmful deterrents.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions can be taken to reduce predation by marine mammals at aquaculture systems?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several fishing gear modifications show effectiveness at reducing marine mammal entanglement.
[Statement 2]: Deploying fishing gear at different depths proved effective at reducing marine mammal entanglement.
[Statement 3]: A controlled study in the Arafura Sea found that fishing nets deployed 4.5 m below the water surface had fewer entanglements of dolphins than surface nets.
[Statement 4]: Acoustically reflective fishing gear materials demonstrated mixed but promising results in reducing marine mammal entanglement.
[Statement 5]: Two of three controlled studies found that fishing nets made from acoustically reflective materials, such as iron-oxide or barium sulfate, had fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises than conventional fishing nets.
[Statement 6]: One study found that barium sulfate nets did not reduce dolphin entanglements.
[Statement 7]: Catch and hook protection devices showed effectiveness for certain species.
[Statement 8]: One study in the South Pacific Ocean found that using cage or chain devices on fishing hooks resulted in fewer unwanted catches of toothed whales.
[Statement 9]: Several other modification approaches showed no evidence of effectiveness.
[Statement 10]: Stiffened materials or increased tension in fishing nets did not reduce Franciscana dolphin entanglements in one controlled study.
[Statement 11]: There are no available studies evaluating the effectiveness of biodegradable fishing gear on marine mammal populations.
[Statement 12]: There are no available studies evaluating the effectiveness of weakened fishing gear on marine mammal populations.
[Statement 13]: There are no available studies evaluating the effectiveness of smaller mesh sizes on marine mammal populations.
[Statement 14]: There are no available studies evaluating the effectiveness of limiting fishing gear length on marine mammal populations.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Which modifications to fishing gear are most effective at reducing marine mammal entanglement?
_claude-sonnet-4__What are the population-level effects of legally protecting marine mammal species or their habitats?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Studies have documented several population-level effects of legal protection for marine mammals and their habitats.
[Statement 2]: Legal habitat protection showed positive population responses in four studies across different regions.
[Statement 3]: A study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that Mediterranean monk seal populations increased during eight years after the islands the seals inhabited were legally protected.
[Statement 4]: A study in the South Pacific Ocean found that Hector's dolphin survival rates were higher after a coastal area was legally protected than before the area was protected.
[Statement 5]: One study in the North Sea found that bottlenose dolphin population size remained similar before and after part of the bottlenose dolphins' range was protected.
[Statement 6]: A study in the Port River estuary found that after legal protection, similar numbers of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphin strandings were recorded compared to before protection was in place.
[Statement 7]: A study in the Port River estuary found that after legal protection, human-caused strandings of Indo-Pacific bottlenose dolphins decreased.
[Statement 8]: Prohibiting hunting of marine mammal species demonstrated strong population effects in five studies.
[Statement 9]: Four of five studies found that after hunting was prohibited, harbor seal and humpback whale abundance increased over 7-30 years in the Kattegat and Skagerrak Seas, South Pacific Ocean, North Atlantic Ocean, and Southern Ocean.
[Statement 10]: One review covering the North Atlantic Ocean, North Pacific Ocean and Southern Hemisphere found significant increase rates for 10 of 12 baleen whale populations during 7-21 years after legislation prohibiting hunting was introduced.
[Statement 11]: One study found that mature male sperm whale numbers did not differ significantly before or 31 years after hunting was prohibited.
[Statement 12]: Prohibiting activities that cause disturbance in sensitive areas showed positive effects in limited studies.
[Statement 13]: One study in the Kattegat Sea found that harbor porpoise activity increased at a stony reef after fishing was prohibited and the reef was restored.
[Statement 14]: A study in the Indian Ocean found that a beach with fully prohibited human access had fewer Australian sea lions showing aggression or retreating compared to a beach with partial access restrictions.
[Statement 15]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of directly legally protecting marine and freshwater mammal species.
[Statement 16]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of enforcing existing legislation for habitat protection.
[Statement 17]: No studies were found that evaluated the effects of establishing networks of legally protected areas.

[Statement 1]: The evidence for interventions aimed at reducing lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals is extremely limited.
[Statement 2]: Among the various intervention strategies examined, only setting and enforcing vessel speed limits has been evaluated with actual evidence.
[Statement 3]: Two studies evaluated the effects of setting and enforcing vessel speed limits.
[Statement 4]: One before-and-after study in the Indian River estuarine system found similar numbers of manatee deaths before and after vessel speed limits were set in 'zones'.
[Statement 5]: Fewer manatee deaths were recorded in the Indian River estuarine system after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas.
[Statement 6]: A before-and-after study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that setting vessel speed limits during specific periods in key habitats resulted in fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths caused by collisions.
[Statement 7]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of diverting shipping routes.
[Statement 8]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of using observers on board vessels to detect mammals.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of reducing shipping along inland waterways.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of developing and implementing regulations for operating vessels around mammals.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of using remote tools to detect mammals.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of using real-time automated tools on board vessels to detect mammals.
[Statement 13]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of limiting vessel traffic in shallow rivers.
[Statement 14]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of using acoustic devices on moving vessels.
[Statement 15]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of providing training to vessel operators on mammal behaviour and appropriate avoidance techniques.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the state of the evidence for interventions aimed at reducing lethal vessel collisions with marine mammals?
_claude-sonnet-4__How do the outcomes of translocating marine mammals vary depending on the conservation goal, based on studies from the Pacific and Tasman Sea regions?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Based on studies from the Pacific and Tasman Sea regions, marine mammal translocation outcomes vary significantly depending on conservation goals.
[Statement 2]: For population re-establishment goals in the North Pacific Ocean, studies on Hawaiian monk seals showed positive outcomes.
[Statement 3]: 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
[Statement 4]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
[Statement 5]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had greater survival rates than non-translocated pups remaining at the original site.
[Statement 6]: More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
[Statement 7]: More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals survived when translocation was combined with at least seven other survival enhancement interventions.
[Statement 8]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups showed similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites.
[Statement 9]: For human-wildlife conflict reduction goals in the Tasman Sea and Southern Ocean around Tasmania, two studies found that translocation was less effective.
[Statement 10]: More than half of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned to the original location.
[Statement 11]: Nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned to the original location.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for the long-term survival of marine mammals following rescue or rehabilitation and release?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Evidence for long-term survival of marine mammals following rescue or rehabilitation and release comes from multiple studies.
[Statement 2]: In 21 studies of rehabilitated and released injured, sick or weak marine mammals, 10-100% of dolphins, porpoises, whales, seals, sea lions and manatees survived.
[Statement 3]: The survival of these rehabilitated marine mammals was monitored during post-release periods ranging from three days to five years.
[Statement 4]: In seven studies of rescued and released stranded or trapped marine mammals, 17-100% of Atlantic white-sided dolphins, short-beaked common dolphins, common bottlenose dolphins, long-finned pilot whales, short-finned pilot whales, and Cape fur seals survived.
[Statement 5]: The survival of these rescued marine mammals was monitored during post-release periods ranging from three weeks to three years.
[Statement 6]: More than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
[Statement 7]: A stranded common bottlenose dolphin was observed with a calf a year after its rescue and release.
[Statement 8]: More than a quarter of Hawaiian monk seals survived after rescue, release and other interventions.
[Statement 9]: Approximately three-quarters of Antillean manatees that were captive-reared and released were known to survive for at least one year.
[Statement 10]: Approximately two-thirds of Florida manatees that were captive-reared and released were known to survive for at least one year.
[Statement 11]: Some captive-reared and released manatees survived for more than seven years.
[Statement 12]: Captive-reared and released Pacific harbour seal pups had similar survival estimates to wild pups.
[Statement 13]: Two of three Antillean manatees born in captivity survived for at least one year without further intervention after release.
[Statement 14]: Two of fourteen Florida manatees born in captivity survived for at least one year without further intervention after release.

[Statement 1]: Several actions are available to reduce human-wildlife conflict at commercial fisheries in riverine systems based on documented studies.
[Statement 2]: Installing barriers at wild fisheries has been tested.
[Statement 3]: A study in the Puntledge River found that installing a 'cork line' barrier did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
[Statement 4]: Anti-predator nets can be effective when properly maintained.
[Statement 5]: A study in the North Atlantic Ocean found that replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
[Statement 6]: Acoustic devices show mixed effectiveness.
[Statement 7]: At aquaculture systems, some studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
[Statement 8]: Some studies at aquaculture systems found acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
[Statement 9]: Two studies found that acoustic devices had no effect on harbour seal predation or dolphin presence at aquaculture systems.
[Statement 10]: On fishing gear, studies found acoustic devices resulted in fewer entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans.
[Statement 11]: Studies found acoustic devices on fishing gear reduced damage to fish catches and fishing nets caused by dolphins and seals.
[Statement 12]: On fishing vessels, acoustic devices had limited success for conflict reduction.
[Statement 13]: One study found that acoustic devices on fishing vessels did not reduce the predation of squid catches by dolphins.
[Statement 14]: Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries was tested in one study in the Puntledge River.
[Statement 15]: Switching off artificial lighting did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery in one study.
[Statement 16]: Translocating mammals away from aquaculture systems has limited long-term effectiveness.
[Statement 17]: Studies in the Tasman Sea found that more than half or nearly all of translocated Australian and New Zealand fur seals returned to salmon farms.
[Statement 18]: Regulatory actions to prevent harmful deterrents at aquaculture systems and wild fisheries exist.
[Statement 19]: The effectiveness of two existing regulatory actions to prevent harmful deterrents at aquaculture systems and wild fisheries has not been evaluated in documented studies.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What actions are available to reduce human-wildlife conflict at commercial fisheries in riverine systems?
_claude-sonnet-4__What is the evidence for the success of interventions like translocation and rehabilitation for Hawaiian monk seals in the North Pacific Ocean?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
[Statement 2]: 52% of rehabilitated and translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
[Statement 3]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
[Statement 4]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had greater survival rates than non-translocated pups remaining at the original site.
[Statement 5]: More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced when combined with rehabilitation or at least seven other interventions to enhance survival.
[Statement 6]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites.
[Statement 7]: More than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
[Statement 8]: Studies found that 10-100% of Hawaiian monk seals released after rehabilitation in captivity survived during post-release monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years.
[Statement 9]: Removing aggressive male Hawaiian monk seals increased the survival of adult female Hawaiian monk seals.
[Statement 10]: Removing aggressive male Hawaiian monk seals resulted in fewer female Hawaiian monk seals being injured.
[Statement 11]: Reuniting Hawaiian monk seal pups with their mothers, along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival, resulted in more than a quarter of the seals reproducing.
[Statement 12]: Reuniting Hawaiian monk seal pups with their mothers, along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival, resulted in more than a quarter of the seals surviving.
[Statement 13]: Rescuing and releasing stranded or trapped Hawaiian monk seals, along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival, resulted in more than a quarter of the seals reproducing.
[Statement 14]: Rescuing and releasing stranded or trapped Hawaiian monk seals, along with at least seven other interventions to enhance survival, resulted in more than a quarter of the seals surviving.

[Statement 1]: The non-lethal alternatives for managing marine mammal presence and predation at aquaculture facilities include acoustic devices, anti-predator nets, translocation, and diversionary feeding.
[Statement 2]: Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems showed mixed effectiveness across several studies.
[Statement 3]: Four studies found that acoustic devices reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
[Statement 4]: Some studies found that acoustic devices reduced the number of harbour seals approaching fish cages.
[Statement 5]: Two studies found no reduction in harbour seal predation from the use of acoustic devices.
[Statement 6]: Two studies found no reduction in the presence of common bottlenose dolphins around fin-fish farms from the use of acoustic devices.
[Statement 7]: Anti-predator nets are used as physical barriers at aquaculture facilities.
[Statement 8]: One study found that replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of modifying anti-predator nets around aquaculture systems.
[Statement 10]: The translocation of mammals away from aquaculture systems showed limited effectiveness.
[Statement 11]: More than half or nearly all Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned.
[Statement 12]: Diversionary feeding has been studied to reduce nuisance behaviour and human-wildlife conflict with mammals.
[Statement 13]: Two studies in the USA found that diversionary feeding reduced nuisance behaviour by black bears.
[Statement 14]: Other potential alternatives for managing marine mammals include minimizing food waste at aquaculture systems and modifying aquaculture gear.
[Statement 15]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of minimizing food waste or modifying aquaculture gear on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 16]: Installing barriers at wild fisheries showed poor results for deterring marine mammals.
[Statement 17]: One study found that a cork line barrier did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the non-lethal alternatives for managing marine mammal presence and predation at aquaculture facilities, and how effective are they?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several non-lethal methods have been evaluated for reducing human-wildlife conflict involving seals at wild fisheries.
[Statement 2]: Installing steel rods on lobster pots or metal frames on fishing pots reduced the number of Australian sea lion pups or grey seals and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in pots.
[Statement 3]: Installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets or bag-nets, along with strengthened netting or other modifications to prevent seal access, reduced damage to salmon catches by seals.
[Statement 4]: Installing exclusion and/or escape devices on trawl nets reduced the number of trapped or entangled Antarctic fur seals.
[Statement 5]: Fewer fur seals died in exclusion devices with large escape openings than in those with small openings.
[Statement 6]: Using acoustic devices on fishing nets resulted in seals approaching nets less closely, having fewer encounters or interactions with nets, or reduced activity and sightings in the surrounding area.
[Statement 7]: Acoustic devices reduced damage to fish catches and/or fishing nets caused by seals.
[Statement 8]: Deploying an acoustic device on a mooring reduced the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon.
[Statement 9]: Deploying acoustic devices on moorings reduced numbers of grey and harbour seals.
[Statement 10]: Installing a 'cork line' barrier did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
[Statement 11]: Switching off artificial lights on a bridge did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
[Statement 12]: Attaching acrylic beads next to fishing hooks did not reduce predation on fish catches by sperm whales.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the most beneficial non-lethal methods for reducing human-wildlife conflict at wild fisheries involving seals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Physical modifications to fishing gear for reducing porpoise and dolphin entanglement include several approaches.
[Statement 2]: Gillnet or entangling net configuration can be modified through reduced height, increased tension, twine diameter and mesh size and orientation changes.
[Statement 3]: Fishing nets can be made from acoustically reflective materials containing iron-oxide or barium sulfate.
[Statement 4]: Two of three controlled studies showed that nets made from acoustically reflective materials led to fewer harbour porpoise entanglements compared to conventional nets.
[Statement 5]: Fishing gear can be deployed at different depths.
[Statement 6]: One study showed that nets deployed 4.5 meters below the water surface had fewer dolphin entanglements than surface nets.
[Statement 7]: Exclusion and/or escape devices can be installed on fishing nets.
[Statement 8]: Studies have shown that installing exclusion or escape devices on fishing nets reduced the number of trapped or entangled Antarctic fur seals and common bottlenose dolphins.
[Statement 9]: Studies have shown that larger escape openings on fishing gear resulted in fewer fur seal deaths than smaller openings.
[Statement 10]: Different twine types can be used in trawl nets.
[Statement 11]: Studies have examined the effects of twine thickness and construction material on the selectivity of trawl nets.
[Statement 12]: Lights can be added to fishing gear.
[Statement 13]: Studies on adding lights to fishing gear have focused on turtle bycatch reduction rather than on marine mammals.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__Besides acoustic deterrents, what alternative physical modifications can be made to fishing gear to reduce porpoise and dolphin entanglement?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several management actions can reduce disturbance to marine mammals from tourism and recreational activities.
[Statement 2]: Introducing and enforcing regulations for marine and freshwater mammal watching tours has been shown to be effective.
[Statement 3]: When whale-watching vessels followed approach regulations, fewer sperm whales and humpback whale pods changed their behaviours or avoided vessels compared to when regulations were not followed.
[Statement 4]: When tour boats followed approach regulations, fewer Guiana dolphins displayed negative behaviours such as moving away, diving, or group separation.
[Statement 5]: When boats approached seal colonies to 75 meters versus 25 meters, more seals remained on shore.
[Statement 6]: Setting and enforcing vessel speed limits has proven beneficial for marine mammal survival.
[Statement 7]: Studies showed fewer manatee deaths after speed limits were set and enforced in all areas.
[Statement 8]: Fewer North Atlantic right whale deaths were caused by collisions when vessel speed limits were set during specific periods in key habitats.
[Statement 9]: Creating designated areas or access points for recreational activities is a potential management action to reduce disturbance to marine mammals.
[Statement 10]: Introducing permits or licences for recreational watersports is a potential management action to reduce disturbance to marine mammals.
[Statement 11]: Introducing permits or licences for marine mammal watching tours is a potential management action to reduce disturbance to marine mammals.
[Statement 12]: Developing regulations for operating vessels around mammals is a potential management action.
[Statement 13]: Delaying or ceasing operations if marine mammals are detected within specified zones is a potential management action.
[Statement 14]: Controlling human activity in marine protected areas with zonation systems is a potential management action.
[Statement 15]: No studies were found evaluating the effectiveness of many of the potential management actions on marine mammal populations.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What management actions can reduce disturbance to marine mammals from tourism and recreational activities?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The documented effects of translocating marine mammals for different conservation purposes show varied outcomes depending on the specific purpose.
[Statement 2]: For population re-establishment or boosting native populations, 50-83% of translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups survived for at least one year.
[Statement 3]: For population re-establishment, 52% of rehabilitated and translocated Hawaiian monk seals survived for one year.
[Statement 4]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar survival rates to non-translocated pups born at release sites.
[Statement 5]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had greater survival rates than non-translocated pups that remained at the original site.
[Statement 6]: More than a quarter of translocated Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
[Statement 7]: Translocated Hawaiian monk seal pups had similar dispersal times to non-translocated seal pups born at release sites.
[Statement 8]: For translocation away from contaminated sites, most sea-otters survived for the duration of monitoring.
[Statement 9]: For translocation away from contaminated sites, most sea-otters did not return to their capture location.
[Statement 10]: For stress reduction during translocation, using tranquilizers did not increase post-release survival of European rabbits.
[Statement 11]: For rehabilitation and release, 10-100% of dolphins, porpoises, whales, seals, sea lions and manatees released after rehabilitation survived during post-release monitoring periods ranging from three days to five years.
[Statement 12]: More than a quarter of rehabilitated and released Hawaiian monk seals reproduced.
[Statement 13]: Some rehabilitated animals showed similar movements and behaviors to wild mammals.
[Statement 14]: Other rehabilitated animals showed behavioral differences such as traveling further from shore and making shorter, shallower dives.
[Statement 15]: For captive-bred releases, two of three Antillean manatees born in captivity and released survived for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 16]: For captive-bred releases, two of 14 Florida manatees born in captivity and released survived for at least one year without further intervention.
[Statement 17]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of translocation before the onset of impactful activities.
[Statement 18]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of translocation to reduce disease exposure.
[Statement 19]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of relocation following oil spills.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the documented effects of translocating marine mammals for different conservation purposes?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence regarding actions to reduce pollution from land-based agricultural and municipal sources affecting marine and freshwater mammals shows a consistent lack of empirical studies.
[Statement 2]: Across multiple relevant actions, no studies were found that evaluated the effects of these actions on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 3]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of treating wastewater from intensive livestock holdings on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 4]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of reducing pesticide, herbicide or fertilizer use on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 5]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of regulating the use, dosage and disposal of agrichemicals on marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 6]: For municipal pollution sources, no studies were found evaluating the effects of setting or improving minimum sewage treatment standards on mammal populations.
[Statement 7]: For municipal pollution sources, no studies were found evaluating the effects of limiting storm wastewater overflow on mammal populations.
[Statement 8]: Infrastructure-based solutions to reduce pollution also lack evidence of their effects on mammal populations.
[Statement 9]: No studies were found for establishing riparian buffers to reduce pollutants reaching rivers and the sea.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found for creating artificial wetlands to reduce pollutants reaching rivers and the sea.
[Statement 11]: No studies were found for establishing aquaculture to extract nutrients from run-offs.
[Statement 12]: No studies were found for introducing and enforcing water quality regulations for aquaculture systems.
[Statement 13]: Systematic searches have been unable to assess whether pollution reduction actions are effective for marine and freshwater mammal populations.
[Statement 14]: Systematic searches have been unable to assess whether pollution reduction actions have any harmful impacts on marine and freshwater mammal populations.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What is the state of the evidence regarding actions to reduce pollution from land-based agricultural and municipal sources affecting marine and freshwater mammals?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Several interventions have shown effectiveness for reducing marine mammal bycatch in Australian fisheries.
[Statement 2]: Acoustic devices on fishing gear have been extensively studied and show promising results.
[Statement 3]: Studies demonstrated reduced entanglements of harbour porpoises, Franciscana dolphins, beaked whales and small cetaceans when acoustic devices were used on cod traps or fishing nets.
[Statement 4]: In Australian waters, studies in Moreton Bay, the Rainbow Channel and the Indian Ocean found that acoustic devices on fishing nets resulted in marine mammals approaching nets less closely and having fewer encounters.
[Statement 5]: Deploying fishing gear at different depths has proven effective in Australian waters.
[Statement 6]: A controlled study in the Arafura Sea found that fishing nets deployed 4.5 m below the water surface had fewer entanglements of dolphins than surface nets.
[Statement 7]: Establishing handling and release protocols for captured mammals has shown measurable benefits.
[Statement 8]: A study in the Great Australian Bight found that introducing a code of conduct for releasing dolphins trapped in nets resulted in lower mortality of short-beaked common dolphins.
[Statement 9]: The same study in the Great Australian Bight found that avoiding dolphins during fishing also resulted in lower mortality of short-beaked common dolphins.
[Statement 10]: Move-on rules for fishing vessels when mammals are encountered have demonstrated effectiveness in Australian waters.
[Statement 11]: A study in the Great Australian Bight showed that measures to delay or relocate fishing if dolphins were encountered resulted in fewer short-beaked common dolphins being encircled and killed.
[Statement 12]: Catch and hook protection devices have shown mixed results.
[Statement 13]: Studies in the South Pacific Ocean found that cage or chain devices on fishing hooks resulted in fewer unwanted catches of toothed whales.
[Statement 14]: The effectiveness of cage or chain devices on fishing hooks varied by device type.
[Statement 15]: Acoustic devices on fishing vessels have been tested in Australian waters.
[Statement 16]: Studies in the Rainbow Channel and Keppel Bay showed that acoustic devices deployed alongside vessels reduced surfacing and echolocation rates of Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins and Australian snubfin dolphins.
[Statement 17]: Studies in the Rainbow Channel and Keppel Bay also showed that acoustic devices deployed alongside vessels reduced the time that Indo-Pacific humpback dolphins and Australian snubfin dolphins spent foraging or socializing.

key: _claude-sonnet-4__What are the most beneficial interventions for reducing marine mammal bycatch in Australian fisheries?
_claude-sonnet-4__How does the evidence for mitigating seal predation differ between aquaculture systems and wild fisheries?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: The evidence for mitigating seal predation differs significantly between aquaculture systems and wild fisheries in terms of available research and effectiveness of interventions.
[Statement 2]: For aquaculture systems, replacing anti-predator nets more frequently at salmon farms resulted in fewer salmon losses to harbour seal predation.
[Statement 3]: Acoustic devices at aquaculture systems demonstrated mixed effectiveness in reducing seal predation.
[Statement 4]: Four of six studies showed that using acoustic devices at salmon farms reduced predation on caged salmon by grey seals, harbour seals and South American sea lions.
[Statement 5]: Two studies found that acoustic devices did not reduce harbour seal predation at salmon farms.
[Statement 6]: Translocation of mammals away from aquaculture systems showed limited effectiveness.
[Statement 7]: More than half or nearly all of Australian and New Zealand fur seals translocated away from salmon farms returned to the farms.
[Statement 8]: For wild fisheries, the evidence on mitigating seal predation is more limited and shows different patterns.
[Statement 9]: Modifying fishing pots and traps to exclude mammals showed positive results.
[Statement 10]: Studies found that installing steel rods on lobster pots or metal frames on fishing pots reduced the number of Australian sea lion pups or grey seals and harbour seals that entered or became trapped in pots.
[Statement 11]: Installing wire grids or steel bars on fishing trap-nets reduced damage to salmon catches by seals.
[Statement 12]: Acoustic devices on moorings in wild fisheries showed variable effectiveness.
[Statement 13]: One randomized controlled study found that deploying an acoustic device on a mooring reduced the number of harbour seals feeding on migrating juvenile salmon.
[Statement 14]: Other studies on acoustic devices in wild fisheries showed mixed results on marine mammal behavior.
[Statement 15]: Installing barriers at wild fisheries showed no effectiveness in deterring seals.
[Statement 16]: Switching off artificial lighting at wild fisheries showed no effectiveness in deterring seals.
[Statement 17]: Studies found that installing barriers and switching off artificial lighting did not deter harbour seals from feeding on salmon released from a hatchery.
[Statement 18]: No studies were found evaluating regulations to prevent harmful deterrents in either aquaculture systems or wild fisheries.
